Hi Physics Girl.

Great video. Just wondering if you have come across a newer idea for pumped-hydro from a group of academics at the Australian National University, lead by Prof Andrew Blakkers.

Off-river pumped hydro. Their idea is simple. Since the amount of energy that can be stored is proportional to the height difference between the two dams/pondages, you want to find sites that have big height differences. And most of these sites aren't next to rivers. They are in other locations, away from a river. The pumped hydro site you visited in California had a height difference of 300 feet. They have identified many 1000's of sites in Australia, and now many, many more around the world, with height differences of up to 600 meters!!! So to store the same amount of energy as that California site, you would only need 15% as much water, and the dams/pondages could be much smaller. Meaning you need to make up less water to account for evaporation.

So, how do you get water for this, if it isn't on a river? Well it might be near a river, say a few km away. So you run a pipeline from the river to fill the pondage as needed.

Or, you use evaporation suppression systems - essentially covering the dam/pondage - to reduce evaporation. The best evap' suppression systems reduce evaporation by 70-90%. Typical annual evaporation losses for open water in a medium climate, not desert, may be 2-3 meters per year. But if ideally you could reduce that by 90%, that is just 20-30 cm per year. If you have a halfway decent annual rainfall, say 0.5 - 1 meters per year natural rainfall will keep it filled. And even a year or few of drought would still only lower water levels by a meter, and one years average rainfall would refill that.

Their idea would see something like a Turkey's Nest dam built on a suitable hilltop, built mainly from earth and rock excavated out of the hilltop, and a second pondage at the base of the hill. They might be on private land, and they don't need to be concerned about having large catchments around them.

And there are huge numbers of potential sites - nowhere near built out yet.

Here is a link to the map of potential sites, worldwide, at ANU.

https://www.anu.edu.au/news/all-news/anu-finds-530000-potential-pumped-hydro-sites-worldwide

Unlike what the doofus says at 4:05, solar power sources have no problem being disconnected from the grid. PV modules are one of the few power sources that have no issues being used from 0 to 100% of their capacity at any time. They do not "force" power onto the grid, and can be ramped up and down in milliseconds. Large rotating kinetic mass generators such as the hydro generators need much longer to change power output, and will "force" power onto the grid until they can be ramped down. Wind generators are also rotating kinetic mass generators (albeit much smaller than most large hydropower generators), but depending on their configuration, are very easy to change power output, and bring online or take offline when needed.

As an electrician who has worked on wind, solar, hydro, combined cycle, and nuclear plants, nuclear power is highly overrated, and THE most expensive source of power available, along with not actually being low carbon when the entire construction, fuel cycle, decommissioning, and long term wast storage is considered. The US has spent, on average in inflation adjusted dollars of DIRECT taxpayer subsidies, 3.5 billion dollars per year since 1948 on nuclear power, yet it is our most expensive source of grid scale power (120 to 180 dollars per mega Watt hour). Renewables have received 0.38 billion in direct taxpayer subsidies a year since 1994, and are the cheapest source of grid scale power today (25 to 50 dollars per mega Watt hour).

Nuclear power also has a huge indirect cost to taxpayers in security, insurance indemnification, and unknown waste disposal cost for tens of thousands of years. The total insurance pool for nuclear power reactors in the US is around 13.5 billion dollars. As the Fukushima disaster is reaching a trillion dollars, if the US had a similar disaster, the US taxpayers would be on the hook for the remaining 986.5 billion dollars.

The critical problems of storage become vastly simpler and less expensive, and therefore easier to implement, if you don't try to get to 100% intermittent renewables. Providing even 20% of our electricity from nuclear would be a huge help, and between uranium and thorium fuel cycles, along with reactors burning existing nuclear waste for energy, we have enough fuel for many centuries if not millennia.

The cost difference of storage needs between 80% renewables and 100% is huge. For example, a major study on storage needs for California by The Clean Air Task Force (a respected climate change charity and think tank), found that at 80% renewables you would need 9.6 million megawatt-hours of energy storage and 36.3 million mWh at 100%. Almost 4 times as much storage just to get the last 20%. Maintaining that storage reserve (a great deal of it unused most of the time) is expensive and that cost has to be paid for by electricity users, resulting an an effective net production cost of $1612 per mWh at 100% renewables. Compare that to about $160 pr mWh, the high end of costs for electricity from new nuclear power plants... often derided as 'too expensive.' In reality, it is not including nuclear in our clean energy mix that is too expensive. It is certainly possible to make 100% renewables work. It just takes even longer than building new nuclear plants and costs 10x as much.

As for safety, the reality is that we have been misled for decades about nuclear power by activists who, however well meaning, can't or won't understand that nuclear power and nuclear weapons aren't the same thing. Even when waste and accidents are considered, the number of lives lost per mWh for nuclear is comparable to that from solar and wind power, all vastly less than the death toll from fossil fuels. Just the small particulates alone from coal kills as many people every 7 hours as the high end calculation of the eventual total death toll at Fukushima. The problems of waste are far more manageable when you don't use 5% of the energy in the fuel and call the rest waste like we do now. Instead use it for fuel in other type of reactors. This video is wrong. The first step towards reaching a zero emissions economy, is to reduce the CO2 production of the electricity infrastructure to 50% of it's current value. This is readily achieved by solar panels alone, without the need to build even 1 kWh of battery or other form of energy storage.

Solar photovoltaic panels have gotten so cheap in recent times, that they produce the cheapest form of energy of all the mainstream existing technologies (the only potential exception being wood harvested on your own land using your own labor, where you value your time and risk of injury at $0/hour). A properly implemented solar photovoltaic array can generate electricity at 2 cents / kWh, when the panels and support equipment is amortized over a 20 year or longer timescale (most solar panels come with a 20 or 25 year warrantee, and getting well over 20 years of practical service is realistic).

If you 3x overbuild your solar array size (such that you are wasting 2x of your base energy needs, on sunny days), the useful electricity it produces will be 3x as expensive, so around 6 cents / kWh, which is still cheaper than what the vast majority of electricity consumers pay today. Consequently, it is economically sensible to 3x overbuild solar panels. Doing so also provides highly reliable electricity, even on cloudy days, since on completely and continuously cloudy days (but without precipitation), solar panels generally still produce around 30% or more of their full sun day output values.

If we did 3x overbuild solar panels, we could nearly 100% shutdown all combustion power plants, during the daytime hours. This would in effect reduce the CO2 production intensity of the electric grid to roughly 50% of the current values, since the combustion plants would only be operating during the nighttime hours of the day.

Once you have so many solar panels installed, there will be massive surpluses of electricity during sunny daytime conditions, since the system is 3x overbuilt to meet the normal daytime energy needs of society. You can then use some of this "surplus" electricity for electric car charging purposes (assuming people go to the trouble of installing charging ports at places of employment). The rest of the electricity can be put to valuable use as low priority industrial energy, for energy intensive activities, such as metals refining and reduction (ex: making iron from iron oxide for instance).

Then, if people buy enough electric vehicles, and the electric vehicles are designed with high cycle life batteries in them (ex: lithium iron phosphate could be used, which often provides manufacturer claimed cycle life of 4000-20,000 cycles at 80% depth of discharge), the electric vehicles can be used to perform car to grid and grid to car storage operations. High cycle life batteries are somewhat expensive on their own, but when you are buying them primarily for a high value use purpose (ex: as part of an electric car), they are very cost effective, and can serve a dual use purpose of storing vehicle propulsion energy, in addition to providing grid energy storage (some of which will be consumable during the nighttime hours of the day, using stored solar energy from the daytime hours). Eventually, a zero emissions economy becomes realized, where long range, high cycle life, car to grid/grid to car capable electric vehicles are providing the majority of the necessary electricity grid energy storage for nighttime consumption.

Thus, there is no grid energy storage "problem" at present. The current problem, is that society is not yet embracing solar photovoltaic panels fully. They are good tech, but they are highly underutilized at present. Simply building and hooking up far more of them, is the first step towards a zero emissions economy. Energy storage technology is not the problem, as the current problem is one of human behavior, that is, most people just aren't doing the right actions to build the necessary solar panel manufacturing plants, and then running them at full capacity to build the necessary solar panels.

My company has looked at compressed air energy storage with an interesting twist :  a “normal” compressed air storage tank (on land) requires a strong tank or pressure vessel to keep it in, and such tanks are heavy and expensive. An alternative is to build a thin walled tank with little inherent strength (hence cheaper) but place it in deep water, eg in the ocean hundreds of meters deep.  At that depth the hydrostatic pressure of the water acts to provide all the containment pressure. The tank is open to the sea at the bottom and is initially filled with water at the same pressure as the water outside, so there is no net force on the tank walls. Compressed air is piped from the surface down into the tank, displacing the water inside which exits through the bottom. The air pressure inside is automatically equalized with the water pressure outside , again resulting in no net force on the tank walls, sort of like a diving bell.  To recover the energy water is allowed back in, forcing the high pressure air back up the pipe to (you guessed it ) drive a turbine.

Until recently I mistakenly thought that our largest reservoirs had the capacity to last over a year or two of droughts, but then a youtube video about the UK energy grid inspired me to do the math, and it turned out that we don't have even a very small fraction of that. :-(
We also have one of the larger pumped storage systems in the world, but its capacity is such a small fraction of the total generating capacity that in reality it is cheaper to simply adjust the production rates and reserve those pumps for shorter periods of extreme rainfall when the main reservoirs are almost filled to capacity, i.e. when the only alternative is to just let the water bypass the generator turbines. Going to a net zero future will require orders of magnitude improvements in storage, just to cover those nights when it is also calm.

Also, the one I think is the coolest is Eduard Heindl's gravity storage concept where an enormous piston is excavated out of the bedrock itself, a large, heavy-duty gasket is installed around it, and water is pumped from underground reservoirs to lift the piston when you have a surplus, and then you let gravity lower the piston when you need to get the energy back. This system would by and large work with existing pumped hydro technology but without the geological requirements, the need for as much water, or the vulnerability to evaporation. It's also very scalable thanks to basic geometry--if you double the circumference of the piston, it costs roughly twice as much to build, but gives you four times as much storage capacity!

For hydrogen storage, there's a bit of a matrix. Trying to store pure hydrogen in any sort of compressed form is generally a non-starter, but the cheapest fuel cell technologies require pure hydrogen. Using heavier hydrocarbons like natural gas are easier to compress and store, but the fuel cell assembly is more complex and expensive because of the heating required to separate the hydrogen out.

Its a bit of a conundrum. One solution is to not try to compress the hydrogen directly but instead store it in a metal oxide (catalytic) chemical matrix that yields good densities but does not require high compression, cryo, or heating. This works quite well but again require a certain degree of complexity... low pressure pumps, valves, plus the metal oxide canister has limited life (~15 years or so, though that isn't a big deal). All in addition to the power electronics. More things can break, basically.

This is why batteries are going to remain popular for a very long time, and perhaps even more so once the technology shifts over to solid electrolytes. Batteries have higher costs up-front, but essentially zero maintenance for 15 years. The life-span of small and medium-scale power electronics under regular cycling is also around 15-20 years and this has to be taken into account too... unavoidable since all of these systems need such electronics regardless.

Great video but somehow missed the heart of the whole problem with grid level energy storage. The shear scale of the energy involved is the problem.
Looking at the UK for a full battery storage system for the whole grid.
(Calculated in 2020-01, Assuming 100% renewable, 50/50 wind turbine and solar.)
My rough back of envelope estimate for the energy required was about 50% of average load (34 GW) to cover 1 day.
That yields a basic storage requirement of about 1430 Terajoules. The power output needs might exceed 15 Gigawatts.

(That 'duck' diagram probably works much better for hot countries where power use coincides better with energy production.)

In bomb terms the total energy stored is equivalent to about 340 Kilotons of TNT.
Even divided into say 100 separate units that's still a pretty huge explosive yield on each battery.
Even greater sub-division like Tesla's Power Wall system solves this has its own problems, different but still huge.

The biggest problem though is the simple scales required. Every joule stored has to be generated somewhere first and that increases the total base-load power required by some 1/3 to 1/2.
Total cycle efficiency in any such grid scale storage system also becomes critical because it increases the size of the base-load further.

Australians can buy a zinc-bromine flow battery for their homes from RedFlow. It's called the ZCell. Unlike some other flow battery chemistries, zinc-bromine plates the zinc onto one of the electrodes during charging, then it's redissolved and put back into solution during discharge. The quirky thing about this is that all zinc must be dissolved off the electrode, or it can form dendrites that will eventually short out the cell. And so every few cycles the battery must be full discharged. So after it's down to zero, it's shorted out for about half an hour just to make sure it's dead. Most practical systems will have two battery banks. When one is completely discharged and sitting there shorted out, the other has power. The ZCell is 48 volt, 220 Amp-Hour.

10:11 TPV uses mirrors and its efficiency is 50%. But mirrors absorb some amount (significant) while reflecting the light rays back. Instead of mirrors, I would suggest the use of Total Internal Reflection (TIR). In TIR, the light rays travel from Denser to Rarer Medium. We can calculate the critical angle of the denser medium using the refractive index of the two medium and then create a prism arrangement and place the entire TPV inside of it. As the light which passes through the PV will hit the rarer medium, the incident angle will be greater than the critical angle and hence lead to total internal reflection of light which will bounce it back to the other side of the prism which will further bounce it back to the PV. This is way more efficient than using mirrors as it absorbs absolutely no energy. Therefore we can increase the efficiency of this method to about 55-60%.

About 20 years ago when I was in high school I learned about this startup company promising a hydrogen fuel cell car, Anuvu. They made some wild awesome claims about their tech, which obviously never came. Later in college I wrote and delivered a persuasive speech encouraging my classmates to drive hydrogen cars when they come available. One of my primary arguments was that given the efficiency of the vaporware Anuvu PEM fuel cell and liquid H2 storage they could expect comparable fuel mileage to the Toyota Prius of the time.

But as time wore on the realities of H2 economy became more apparent. Real PEM efficiencies were much lower than Anuvu promised. People probably weren't going to carry liquid H2 in their car. And the Toyota Prius became much more efficient. Eventually, when learning about the plug to pavement efficiency of BEV's, it became clear: H2 is not the answer. It's not just that round trip efficiency is worse than every other storage method. There are other things that we have to worry about. Hydrogen is very difficult to contain, so leak management must be much better than our current methane infrastructure. Second, once hydrogen escapes from our storage and transport system, which it will, it's gone forever. That may not seem like a big deal, but consider that every two hydrogen atoms lost is also a water molecule lost, and an extra oxygen atom in the atmosphere. At the scale of the rest of human civilization, that might be a problem. Lastly, the metals involved in PEM fuel cels are very expensive and finite. Clearly it's not the answer and I think we're fools to chase that dream.

I researched "Grid Level Energy Storage" in 2014 for my chemical engineering design class my senior year of college. I remembered a few of the storage options presented in this video, but I was actually able to find the presentation and it's interesting to me how it matches up 7 years later.

Our criteria, in order of weight, were as follows.
30% - Longevity of the battery, targeting 25+ years, or ~10,000 charge cycles, of useable life and weatherability
30% - Performance, targeting 90% energy efficiency with high energy-density, ideally as good or better than Li-ion 250 Wh/kg, and ability to store up to 500 MWh of electricity (to replace the avg coal plant)
20% - Toxicity of the materials used in the energy storage- this is probably the weakest criteria in the presentation
10% - Infrastructure required to make/use the energy
10% - Cost of storage method in $/kWh

The most promising energy storage we found via these criteria was a liquid metal battery. From our research we found they would last conservatively for 15+ years, have up to 90% energy efficiency with around 200 Wh/kg energy density, plentiful and (relatively) low toxicity elements Magnesium and Antimony (generally any 2 metals with different densities), and a projected cost of ~$50/kWh once production is in full swing. Nice to see that one of our sources at the time, Ambri, is still chugging along and making their batteries. https://ambri.com/technology/

Next best in our estimation was 'pump-storage', which as Dianna has thoroughly described it is widely used, has good efficiency and makes use of existing geographies to store energy, but the downfalls are that there's not much room to expand and there is a high capital cost to create more storage of this type.

3rd was the Vanadium flow battery, which again I don't need to rehash since the video has the same conclusions our group came to. Easier to scale than Li-ion, but otherwise not much of an improvement.

Last in our estimation was scaling Li-ion batteries to grid-level energy storage. The safety concerns along with limited availability of Lithium create the need for other sources.

One interesting addendum to the project was a zinc-air battery that was in early stages of research in NYC. This was essentially zinc cells in a shipping container, which was a funny picture to me. https://www.aiche.org/chenected/2014/07/testing-zinc-air-battery-storage-new-york-city-grid

The problem I keep circling around and cannot come to resolution on is the true need for long-term storage. It seems the most promising techniques for longer-term storage involve processes that have lower round-trip efficiencies. Unless the capital cost is dramatically lower than for those of Li-ion or LFE batteries or pumped hydro or gravity storage they will not be competitive for managing the daily duck curve. This pushes their utilization to weather or season-based scales. Reducing the number of storage cycles per annum increases the cost of energy per cycle due to capital and operational costs.

It seems to me the primary competitor will rapidly become installing renewable energy overcapacity and living with the curtailment during favorable weather or seasons. Curtailment raises the cost of produced energy for similar reasons reduced cycles increase the cost of stored energy on the long-term storage plants. Many view curtailment of renewable energy as a bad thing, but in practice, that is the way the fossil-fuel plants on the electrical grid operate today. The cheaper plants can bid to run near continuously while the more expensive plants only get the opportunity to run during peak energy demand. The reduced operating hours per year adds to their cost of energy.

Long-term stored energy will have to prove more cost-effective than bringing curtailed generation on-line.
